value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">32</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">beyond recall.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Presumably the earlier plays, in
            <choice>
              <sic>whichnthe</sic>
              <corr>which the</corr>
            </choice> 
            <choice>
              <sic>pplaywright</sic>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">was more at 
            <choice>
              <sic>tge</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> mercy of the audience, are <add hand="typewriter" place="above">the</add> more damaged</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by 
            <choice>
              <sic>rreading</sic>
              <corr>reading</corr>
            </choice> them xmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxx The reader instinctively</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">tries to be there in person. He tries to 
            <choice>
              <sic>sup ly</sic>
              <corr>supply</corr>
            </choice> the 
            <choice>
              <sic>trumepts</sic>
              <corr>trumpets</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and the flags; the citizens and the apprentices.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">He furbishes himself <add hand="typewriter" place="above">nourishes himself</add> with a dip into <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-phen" key="Henslowe, Philip">
            <choice>
              <sic>hensloew</sic>
              <corr>Henslowe</corr>
            </choice></rs>,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">with a dip into <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-rhol" key="Holinshed, Raphael">
            <choice>
              <sic>Holingshed</sic>
              <corr>Holinshed</corr>
            </choice></rs>. He makes an effort to 
            <choice>
              <sic>sppply</sic>
              <corr>supply</corr>
            </choice> what</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>is so obviously</del> the sunk part of the play. But he is 
            <choice>
              <sic>perp</sic>
              <corr>perpetually</corr>
            </choice></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>tually</sic>
              <corr>perpetually</corr>
            </choice> rebuffed. He is apt <add hand="ms" place="above">pat</add> to become not a reader but a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">student; txmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxmmxmxmx a collector of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">scattered bones. At some point however in the Elizabethan</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">drama the 
            <choice>
              <sic>rezder</sic>
              <corr>reader</corr>
            </choice> is born. There are 
            <choice>
              <sic>spepeches</sic>
              <corr>speeches</corr>
            </choice> and 
            <choice>
              <sic>scnes</sic>
              <corr>scenes</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">that call upon his special faculty. When the dramatist</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">becomes conscious of the play as a work of art; when he</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">becomes able to unite the play by a unity which is</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">not that of the plot-- by something in himself <add hand="ms" place="inline">his [illeg.], his [illeg.]</add></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by some individuality of his style, of his whole temper,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><add hand="typewriter" place="above">It is the apprehension of this power at work</add></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del hand="ms">it is this apprehension</del> that serves to 
            <choice>
              <sic>drow</sic>
              <corr>draw</corr>
            </choice> together the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">faculties <del hand="ms">which are proper to the reader.</del></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>th t</sic>
              <corr>that</corr>
            </choice> brings the reader into being.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The reader has been in existence for round</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">about four 
            <choice>
              <sic>hubdred</sic>
              <corr>hundred</corr>
            </choice> years. But his life 
            <choice>
              <sic>hisotry</sic>
              <corr>history</corr>
            </choice> is an</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">obscure one. At some point his ear must have lost its 
            <choice>
              <sic>a uten</sic>
              <corr>acuteness</corr>
            </choice></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">acuteness; then his eyes became dull. Then he became word</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">conscious, aware of suggestions and echoes. As time 
            <choice>
              <sic>paassed</sic>
              <corr>passed</corr>
            </choice>,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he imported into the 
            <choice>
              <sic>writteh</sic>
              <corr>written</corr>
            </choice> word much that was</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unintended by the writer. A word spelt in the Elizabethan</l>
